content.description: Climb up and left, following cracks and ledge systems to meet Bisk at about two-thirds height.  Follow the chimney on Bisk to the top.
content.location: Starts at the base of Blistering.

content.description: Climb the gully and traverse right to a belay ledge.  On the second pitch, traverse right, then up to the summit overhang.  Traverse left and climb up to the top.
content.location: It starts in a gully about 30 feet left of the right edge of the northeast face.

content.description: This route begins 25' right of Cornered.  Start up a 20' slab to a ledge.  Continue up a right trending flake with ample patinas and some slightly awkward positioning.  The patinas become more plentiful as you ascend.
content.location: Located on the North face of Turtle Rock.  To start, scramble up and all the way left on a low angle slab to the base of the right facing corner system.

content.description: About 20" right of Bisk, climb a ramp/crack to a ledge, thn follow a steep chimney to the top.

climbs.name: Rehab
climbs.fa: Dave West and Mark Harrell, Nov 1989

content.description: Start on a large boulder, left of Wandering Tortoise. Stand up on good footholds to clip a bolt. Commit to several delicate slab/edge moves to reach a good hold and a small nut placement. Continue to the belay used for Wandering Tortoise and Ripples. Alternatively, traverse to the bolted anchor on the right.
content.protection: One bolt. Several nuts and cams, mostly thin.
content.location: Find the large boulder, with a single bolt above, left of Wandering Tortoise.

content.description: Scramble up to a belay on a large ledge, below the overhang.  Getting your hands out to the lip is easy, but standing up and then climbing over to easier ground is the crux.  It involves liebacking and deep fist jams.  The moves are fun, but the rock quality isn't great.
content.location: This is well right of other other northern end routes, near the Pillars of Pain.  An obvious hand and fist crack goes out through a roof near the top of the wall.  The roof has a wall along one side of the crack.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Start up a decent crack system that quickly ends and puts you onto juggy face moves. Climb past a series of horizontal cracks. A thin cruxy series of moves makes for a good finish up to the 2-bolt anchor.(5.8 PG13; 90-foot rappel)

Pitch 2: From the bolt anchor, traverse right on a vertical face, bop over a small overhang, then climb straight up a steep headwall to the top. (5.8 PG13)

climbs.name: Hand in the Cookie Jar
climbs.fa: Lori Milas and Bob Gaines, July 2021

content.description: Begin just right of Give a Mouse a Cookie and climb a juggy crack system that angles up and right. Move left and crank a thin move to gain a ramp that slants up and left, then lieback a steep, thin flake. Climb up and right to the East Day 2-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Toprope from the 2-bolt anchor of Easy Day. A 2.5-inch CD is useful for a directional.
content.location: Between Give a Mouse a Cookie and Easy Day.

climbs.name: Give a Mouse a Cookie
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Cyndie Bransford, George Armstrong 1993

content.description: Begin just right of Blistering, at an alcove. Climb steep flakes, then move left and mantle up onto a ledge/ramp. Tricky stemming leads to a headwall. Mave a delicate traverse right, then continue up a steep face. Finish by climbing up and right to the 2-bolt anchor of Easy Day.
content.protection: 4 bolts (1/4-inch bolts in need of replacement) and gear to 3-inches. There were 2 fixed pins placed on the first ascent for the start, but they're long gone.
content.location: Start just right of Blistering and about 30 feet left of Easy Day.

climbs.name: Easy Day
climbs.fa: Chris Gonzalez and John Wolfe, Feb. 1977

content.description: Climb a wall and left-leaning ramp to half height, and then go straight up.  This is perhaps the highest quality easy route on the rock.
content.location: This route starts right of Blistering and just left of Turtle Soup, to the right of center on the face.

content.description: I was in a climbing class when we toproped this. Shares Turtle Soup belay ledge for the second pitch.
content.location: Go to the right-most part of Turtle Rock on the northeast face, then go around the edge to a small ledge. Looking at the North Face of Turtle Rock, this is to the left of Touche Away.

content.description: Start near the center of the East Face. Climb straight up passing a roof on the right, move up and left to a belay ledge beneath a chimney. Climb the chimney and continue to the top.
From the Highest Ledge on the left side of the East Face, climb cracks and a corner to a ledge. Climb easy rock up and right to the top or a 5.7 crack, straight up.
I was in a climbing class when we toproped this. Super fun left-facing corner to get to the flake - the wafer.
content.protection: Trad pro up to 3". No bolts that I saw
content.location: The north face of Turtle Rock, about 100 feet right of Touche Away.
